discussion.content: Yes, (B) seems to be the best fit, since in the Connection Event view you should see the blocks and then take particular actions to unblock the connections.

choices.C: Create a new access control policy rule to allow ports 80 and 443 to the FQDN of the web server.
choices.B: Review the output in connection events to validate the block, and modify the policy to allow the traffic.
choices.D: Verify the blocks using the packet capture tool and create a rule with the action monitor for the traffic.
choices.A: Download a PCAP of the traffic to verify the blocks and use the FlexConfig to override the existing policy.

questions.question_text: An administrator receives reports that users cannot access a cloud-hosted web server. The access control policy was recently updated with several new policy additions and URL filtering. What must be done to troubleshoot the issue and restore access without sacrificing the organization's security posture?

A network administrator wants to configure a Cisco Secure Firewall Threat Defense instance managed by Cisco Secure Firewall Management Center to block traffic to known cryptomining networks. Which system settings must the administrator configure in Secure Firewall Management Center to meet the requirement?

discussion.content: Yes, (B) should be a good fit by using the URL category filter and use SI in addition regarding the target network IPs reputation.

APC and SI . My choice is B

Security Intelligence Feed Categories
The following table describes the categories available in the Cisco Talos Intelligence Group (Talos) feeds. These categories are available for both network and URL blocking.

These categories can change over time, so a newly-downloaded feed might have category changes. When configuring Security Intelligence, you can click the info icon next to a category name to see a description.

Cryptomining

Hosts providing remote access to pools and wallets for the purpose of mining cryptocurrency

Selected Answer: AE
AE are correct

The command stats_unified.pl can help you to determine if the managed device does have some data which needs to be sent to FMC. This condition can happen when the managed device and the FMC experience a connectivity issue. The managed device stores the log data onto a hard drive.

admin@FMC:~$ sudo stats_unified.pl

The manage_proc.pl command can reconfigure the correlator on the FMC side.

root@FMC:~# manage_procs.pl

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/firepower/70/configuration/guide/fpmc-config-guide-v70/troubleshooting_the_system.html

questions.question_text: A network engineer detects a connectivity issue between Cisco Secure Firewall Management Center and Cisco Secure Firewall Threat Defense. Initial troubleshooting indicates that heartbeats and events are not being received. The engineer re-establishes the secure channels between both peers. Which two commands must the engineer run to resolve the issue? (Choose two.)

A network administrator is reviewing a packet capture. The packet capture from inside of Cisco Secure Firewall Threat Defense shows the inbound TCP traffic. However, the outbound TCP traffic is not seen in the packet capture from outside Secure Firewall Threat Defense. Which configuration change resolves the issue?

choices.B: Inside interface must be assigned a higher security level.
choices.D: Inside interface must be assigned a lower security level.
choices.A: Packet capture must include UDP traffic.
choices.C: Route to the destination must be added.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I am not sure, but the only option available is C.

First of all, A is totally WTF.
As for B and D, the security level, this is a value that must be set for each interface in ASA, but is not used for anything at all in FTD.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/secure-firewall/management-center/admin/760/management-center-admin-76/health-troubleshoot.html#:~:text=The%20threat%20defense%20does%20not%20use%20the%20security%20level%20for%20anything
indeed when an info is missing the traffic is dropped, if it was a sec level issue the traffic will be denied and it will be shown in the packet cap

questions.question_text: An engineer is troubleshooting an intermittent connectivity issue on a Cisco Secure Firewall Threat Defense appliance and must collect 24 hours' worth of data. The engineer started a packet capture, however it stops prematurely during this time period. The engineer notices that the packet capture buffer size is set to the default of 32 MB. Which buffer size is the maximum that the engineer must set to enable the packet capture to run successfully?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
should be C

This allows you to capture much more many packets in the capture buffer. Additionally, you can increase the size of the capture buffer (by default is 500Kbytes) to a value up 32 Mbytes (buffer option). Finally, as from FTD version 6.3, the file-size option allows you to configure a capture file up to 10GBytes.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/security/firepower-ngfw/215092-analyze-firepower-firewall-captures-to-e.html#:~:text=This%20allows%20you%20to%20capture,capture%20file%20up%20to%2010GBytes.

Selected Answer: C
Cisco Secure Firewall Threat Defense allows a maximum buffer size of 10 GB for packet captures.
